title: Two Deep Learning Approaches for Automated Segmentation of Left Ventricle in Cine Cardiac MRI
summary: This paper introduces LNU-Net and IBU-Net, two novel deep learning architectures based on the U-Net framework, designed for automated left ventricle (LV) segmentation in cine cardiac MRI. These models integrate specialized normalization strategies and data augmentation techniques to enhance performance. The proposed methods experimentally outperform existing state-of-the-art approaches in terms of Dice coefficient and average perpendicular distance on a dataset of 805 MRI images from 45 patients.

title: Adapting Natural Language Processing Models Across Jurisdictions: A pilot Study in Canadian Cancer Registries
summary: This pilot study demonstrates the successful adaptation of transformer-based NLP models across Canadian provincial cancer registries, specifically for classifying pathology reports into cancer/non-cancer and reportable/non-reportable categories. It shows that models pretrained in one jurisdiction can be effectively localized to another with modest fine-tuning, and a novel ensemble approach significantly reduces missed cancers, paving the way for a privacy-preserving, interoperable NLP infrastructure for pan-Canadian cancer surveillance.

title: Modeling Epidemic Dynamics of Mutant Strains with Evolutionary Game-based Vaccination Behavior
summary: This paper introduces an extended SIRS model that distinguishes between original and mutant strain infections and includes a vaccinated compartment. It integrates evolutionary game theory to model individual vaccination decisions influenced by social interactions and the epidemiological situation, coupling these dynamics via the Microscopic Markov Chain Approach (MMCA). The framework effectively mitigates outbreaks and highlights vaccine cost, efficacy, and perceived side effect risk as critical factors influencing vaccination uptake, providing theoretical support for public health policy design.

title: Detecting Performance Degradation under Data Shift in Pathology Vision-Language Model
summary: This paper addresses the critical issue of performance degradation in pathology Vision-Language Models (VLMs) after deployment, which often occurs due to data distribution shifts and is challenging to detect without labeled data. The authors propose a novel framework that combines input-level data shift detection using a developed toolbox (DomainSAT) with a label-free, confidence-based output indicator. Their findings demonstrate that this combined approach provides a more reliable and interpretable method for identifying actual performance degradation in VLMs, enhancing clinical reliability.

title: Human-like AI-based Auto-Field-in-Field Whole-Brain Radiotherapy Treatment Planning With Conversation Large Language Model Feedback
summary: This study introduces an automated whole-brain radiotherapy (WBRT) planning pipeline that integrates a deep learning (DL) model for patient-specific hyperparameter prediction and a large language model (LLM)-based conversational interface for interactive plan refinement. The system demonstrated high clinical acceptability, significantly reduced planning time compared to manual methods, and achieved dosimetric quality equivalent to clinical plans for critical structures, with the LLM successfully improving suboptimal plans.
